moves.1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf: ..this is a typical development of the Sicilian Najdorf 6.Be2 line....
moves.10. Qd2 O-O 11. O-O-O b5: ..both sides are aiming for maximum activity....
moves.12. g4 Bxb3: ..i play this move sometimes as it gives me the option of bringing Nc5 into play..and pressurise the king...
...this is what I was aiming for ....
moves.17. Bxc5: ...white probably assumed dxc5 but the reply is nastier and develops also....
moves.18. Kb1 Rxc5 19. Bc4 Re8 20. Rhf1 Bg5: ...I can now position the bishop to dominate...and also look at a4/a3....
moves.21. Qe2 Bf4 22. Qe4 Qc7: ...making space for Ra8 and drive the pawn up the a file...with a view to Rca5
moves.23. h4 a4 24. Rfe1 axb3 25. axb3 Ra8: ...open file...always good for rooks...and the bishop is very strong...
moves.26. Re2 Rca5 27. Kc2 Ra5a2 28. Kd3 Qd8: ..just looking to reposition the queen ..pressure on h4 but I need to see what white will do next....
moves.29. g5 g6: ..black is safe and I think has the advantage from here....
moves.31. Rxa1 Rxa1 32. Re2: ..a mistake i think..but blacks position is quite strong now...unfortunately for white..his queen is stuck and this is punished....
moves.32... Rd1+:
...several threats for white to deal with but he loses the queen...
Rd2 is met with Rxd2#
Kc2 is met with Rd4 and the Queen has no escape squares...White is the very significant exchange down...and blacks Queen has excellent prospects to get in and continue the harm...
